Rude incompetant staff. We came a distance to see the submarine, asked at the information desk how to get a ticket for the submarine, he said to buy the ticket to the expositions, which we did at the automatic ticket dispenser. We walked through the dilapidated exposition centre all the way around to the submarine entrance. The rude woman there asked for our ticket, which I gave her. She said that the ticket didn't work there and motioned us away. I said (in french) that we had been told at the information desk that this ticket included the submarine. She said you need a reservation for the submarine. I had to ask how to do that. We had to go back to the entrance and line up for half an hour in a ticket line to get a 'creneau' and come all the way back. It took a hour before we could enter. It was interesting to see the int√©rieur of a real submarine, but it was not pleasant...tight and hot and needing to duck (I don't know how submariners do it). The tiny mus√©e part of the submarine exhibit has some interesting parts, but many of the exhibits weren't working. My son liked seeing the submarine, but overall a negative experience.

Submarine  is nice...its a bit crammed up though. Check out the periscope in the submarine expo area...you can see people in the park :D  Visit to the submarine is included in the cite de sciences expo ticket (12 euro)

Visit to a submarine from the 50s which transports us to the last century, a small museum on the theme of very interesting submarines but more aimed at children/schoolchildren.

The Argonaute S636 is a Daphne-type submarine of the French Navy, which was commissioned in the 1960s. This submarine, whose main mission was underwater defense and coastal surveillance, is an example of naval engineering of the time. Although no longer in active service, it remains a symbol of the military innovation of its time. The S636 Argonaut is notable for its relatively small hull and ability to move quickly underwater. It was equipped with torpedoes and advanced navigation systems for its time, making it a key part of France's naval defense for several decades. Its design, while functional and efficient, was more compact compared to more modern submarines. However, a major drawback of this ship is that it was quickly overtaken by technological advances in submarine warfare. With the evolution of nuclear submarine capabilities and detection systems, the Argonaute S636 has become obsolete. It was decommissioned before becoming a museum ship, allowing visitors to discover its history and its role in the French navy. Despite its retirement from active service, the Argonaute remains a fascinating witness to naval history and an example of the submarine technology of its era.

Coming to visit the city of sciences, visit the Argonaute which was free to access during heritage days. Having already visited a submarine in our region (Espadon in St-Nazaire), this allows us to make a comparison. It‚Äôs worth visiting and having this type of machine open to all is fortunate. The visit to the submarine is quite quick. (-30min) Unfortunately, we feel pushed by the other visitors who follow us. Not necessarily time to see everything clearly. But the progress is well done. The exhibition is interesting, it even lasts longer than the visit to the submarine itself when you take the time. During this day, a former submariner was present to talk about his past, his knowledge and his anecdotes about this building that he knew. Too bad he only intervened in the queue.
I missed the qr for the audio explanation But otherwise it's great. I hope that nowadays sailors are better placed to sleep And there are a lot of outside explanations about submarines.

A beautiful history of French navigation. It is impressive by its size and by all the guiding elements that constitute it! War machine, and purpose-built, inside, small spaces that show the difficulty of the crew on board. No comfort and attention to the head, if you are tall! It took a lot of organization to live there.

L'Agronaute de la Villette, located in the heart of Parc de la Villette in Paris, is a hidden treasure for lovers of maritime history and engineering. A former French Navy submarine, it offers a unique dive into the mysterious world of underwater navigation. Inside, visitors can explore the submarine's original layout, providing a striking insight into life aboard such a craft. The exhibit is well designed and informative, making the experience both educational and entertaining.  The on-site team is knowledgeable and friendly, ready to answer any questions you may have. Although the interior space is somewhat confined, as you would expect from a submarine, the tour is well organized to ensure comfort and safety.  For anyone visiting the Parc de la Villette, the Agronaute is a must, offering an educational break in a green setting. A real gem for curious people of all ages!  Note: Be sure to check opening hours before planning your visit.

Visit carried out on Saturday March 11, 2023 at 10 a.m. Very few people in the morning, you can visit the submarine which has remained in its original state since its shutdown. Then you have access to an exhibition which discusses in particular the history of submarines and professions linked to the Seas/Oceans.
Great experience! A must-see in the city of sciences. The ‚Äúunderwater‚Äù exhibition is a good complement. Lots of information. The free audio guide does not work in the submarine.
Surprisingly small (you don't necessarily expect it). But a very nice walk for children and adults who are curious to know what it‚Äôs like inside!

For my part, I discovered the presence of this submarine with my ticket for the city of sciences. You have to reserve a slot, for my part even if it was a little outdated we were able to access it. The children are captivated by the visit. Audio guides are available. In addition, a small exhibition with some games is available at the exit of the submarine.

You come for the visit, you also have a very beautiful exhibition on submarines, their functioning, their history.  Tip: take your headphones and load all the audio guides before entering the Argonaut. It picks up very poorly in this metal box.

A very interesting location and exhibition area about submarines. If you want to visit the interior of the "Argonaute", you should get an admission ticket at the main entrance of the "Cite des sciences et de I'industrie" or online. A real war submarine from the 50s, impressive to see the narrowness of the place and the difficulties of controlling all the equipment given the number of controls, joysticks and dials!! Everything is clear and well explained!
The visit to the submarine is not recommended for claustrophobics but otherwise a nice exhibition for lovers of the great depths.
